questions.text: Using the procedure depicted in the given image, all of the following can be measured, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of spirometry and Functional residual capacity (FRC) cannot be recorded using it. 

The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after the expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume. As residual volume cannot be measured by spirometry, lung capacities that include the residual volume also cannot be measured by spirometry (i.e., FRC and TLC).

Spirometry cannot measure the following lung volumes and capacities:
  • Residual volume (RV)
  • Closing volume (CV)
  • Functional residual capacity (ERV +  RV)
  • Total lung capacity (TLC)

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. Therefore, it gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: The scheme shown in the symbol is
questions.solution:
The above image shows a sanitary napkin under the brand name ‘Freedays’ which is a part of Menstrual Hygiene Scheme.

Menstrual Hygiene Scheme (MHS):

  • Under ARSH (Adolescent Reproductive Sexual Health), a part of RCH – II
  • Adolescent girls : 10 to 19 years, in rural areas are covered

Objectives:

  • To increase awareness on Menstrual Hygiene
  • To increase access to and use of high quality sanitary napkins among adolescent girls in rural areas
  • To ensure safe disposal of Sanitary Napkins in an environmentally friendly manner

Benefits:

  • A pack of 6 sanitary napkins is provided under the NRHM’s brand ‘Freedays’.
  • These napkins are sold to the adolescents girls at Rs. 6 for a pack of 6 napkins by the Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA).
  • On sale of each pack, the ASHA gets an incentive of Rs. 1 per pack besides a free pack of sanitary napkins per month.

 

 

Ref: http://www.nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/mhs/Guidelines/Revised_Guidelines_for_Menstrual_Hygiene_Scheme.pdf

questions.text: The instrument shown in the photograph is
questions.solution:
The above image shows a rubber catheter with a flower shaped ending. This is a Malecot catheter.

The flower shaped ending ensures it is self retaining.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy (SPC)
    • In case of urinary retention when Foley’s catheterisation fails (after two trials)
    • For diversion of urine following bladder, prostate or urethral surgeries
  • Amoebic liver abscess
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Sub phrenic abscess
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Cholecystostomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of the pancreas

Option B: Stomach tube – Feeding in case of gastrostomy.

Option C: Nasogastric tube / Ryle’s tube – Used for Nasogastric feeding / Stomach wash / Aspiration

Option D: Swan Ganz Catheter / Pulmonary artery catheter – Right Heart Catheterization

questions.text: A 1 week old neonate presents with anoxic spells and single S2. Chest X ray of the child is given. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given findings are suggestive of Tetralogy of fallot(TOF). Pulmonary oligemia is seen in TOF and not pulmonary plethora.

The above X-ray classically shows a boot shaped heart(Coeur en sabot) seen in TOF.

Features of TOF:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) - Subpulmonic stenosis
  • Overriding aorta
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

X-ray Features:

  • A "boot-shaped" heart with an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy and concave pulmonary arterial segment.
  • Right-sided aortic arch is seen in 25% of patients with TOF.
  • Pulmonary oligaemia due to decreased pulmonary arterial flow.

questions.text: Which of the following condition has the given ECG changes?
questions.solution:
The given ECG clearly depicts the Delta wave at the start of QRS complex. It is characteristic of WPW syndrome.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles.

ECG Feature:

  • P-R interval <120 ms
  • Slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the "Delta wave"
    • WPW pattern "Type A": Positive delta waves in all precordial leads, with small or absent S waves
    • WPW pattern "Type B": A delta wave is negative, with prominent S waves, in right precordial leads
  • The QRS complex as a whole is slightly widened
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes

questions.text: A fingerprint can contain all except:
questions.solution:
Circles are not a part of classification in the fingerprint system.

Classification of Fingerprint system:

  • Loops (60 – 70%) - most common
  • Whorls (25 – 35%)
  • Arches (6 – 7%)
  • Composite forms (1 – 2%) - least common

Dactylography/ Fingerprint system/ Dermatoglyphics/ Galton system:

  • This is the most reliable method in establishing identity of an individual.
  • It was first used in India by William Herschel and systematized by Sir Francis Galton.
  • First fingerprint bureau was established in Kolkata.
  • Fingerprints can be obtained upto a depth of 0.6 mm from the surface of the skin.
  • Pattern is not inherited and hence paternity cannot be proved with the help of fingerprints.
  • Pattern isn't similar even in identical twins (Quetelet’s law of biological variation).
  • Permanent impairment of fingerprints is seen in leprosy, electric injury and irradiation.
  • Atrophy of the ridges is seen in celiac disease and dermatitis.

questions.text: What is true regarding the following type of distribution:
questions.solution:
The above graph shows a negatively skewed distribution.

For a Negatively Skewed Distribution, Mode > Median > Mean

For a positively skewed distribution, Mean > Median > Mode

For a normal distribution, Mean = Median = Mode

questions.text: The classification of fracture depicted in the below image is
questions.solution:
The above image shows Gardens Classification of Neck Of Femur Fracture. It is the most widely used.

  • Garden stage I: Undisplaced Incomplete, including valgus impacted fractures
  • Garden stage II: Undisplaced Complete
  • Garden stage III: Complete fracture, incompletely displaced
  • Garden stage IV: Complete fracture, completely displaced

Pipkin and Evans Classification are other types of Femoral neck Fracture classification systems.

questions.text: The type of knot shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Surgeon's knot. It is a very stable knot.

Types of knots:

questions.text: The given image is seen characteristically in
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Iris Lisch nodules , characteristic of NF type 1.

Lisch nodules are the most common type of ocular involvement in NF-1.

These nodules are:

  • Melanocytic hamartomas
  • Usually clear yellow to brown,
  • Well-defined,
  • Specific for NF-1
  • Smooth, usually bilateral, dome shaped elevated nodules
  • Usually arise in the first decade

NF type 1 – Diagnostic Criteria

  • Six or more Café au lait spots (1.5 cm or larger -  post-pubertal individuals) or (0.5 cm or larger - in pre-pubertal individuals)
  • Two or more neurofibromas of any type or one or more plexiform neurofibroma
  • Axillary freckling
  • Optic glioma
  • Two or more Lisch nodules
  • A distinctive bony lesion, dysplasia of the sphenoid bone or dysplasia or thinning of long bone cortex
  • A first-degree relative with NF1

 

Any 2 of the above should be positive.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs might have produced the effect in the picture
questions.solution:
Retinoic acid is a teratogenic drug which can cause cleft lip and palate.

Teratogenic effects of retinoic acid include:

  • Bilateral microtia
  • Anotia with stenosis of external ear canal
  • Flat depressed nasal bridge
  • Cleft lip and palate

questions.text: A child accidentally consumed a fruit shown in the picture. Which of the following drugs is used for management
questions.solution:
• The plant shown in the picture is Datura Stramonium.
  • It contains Atropine - Anticholinergic.
  • The drug of choice for Anticholinergic toxicity is Physostigmine.

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

questions.text: The characteristic appearance is seen on barium swallow in
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Corkscrew / Rosary bead appearance of esophagus which is characteristically seen in DES.

Diffuse esophageal spasm

Diagnosis:

  • Barium swallow
    • Corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus, segmental spasm, pseudodiverticulosis appearance.
    • Due to presence of tertiary conctractions.
    • Indicative of advanced disease.
  • Manometry
    • Gold Standard test
    • Simultaneous multi peaked contractions of high amplitude and long duration

A markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic “bird's beak”appearance,  is suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing).

 

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis 
DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) Normal IRPN
Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP
Increased duration of peristalsis
Normal peristalsis
DCI>8000mmHg

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: The diagnosis based on the gross picture of Gall bladder is
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the gallbladder is of Cholesterolosis Gallbladder also known as Strawberry gallbladder.

It reveals:

  • Brick red GB mucosa with Bright yellow flecks of lipid.
  • Multiple cholesterol polyps studding the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: Insula in the following is marked by
questions.solution:
Insula in the above image is represented by B.

Insula is a portion of cerebral cortex folded deep within the floor of lateral sulcus.

Functions:

  • Serving as the primary gustatory cortex.
  • Important connections to language and visual-vestibular integration.
  • Autonomic function - particularly sympathetic tone from the right insula.

Damage to this area has been associated with cardiac arrhythmias.

Other options:

A - Caudate nucleus

B - Insula

C - Lentiform nucleus (Globus pallidus + Putamen)

D - Third ventricle

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He is found to be in hemorrhagic shock. As a part of the ATLS protocol, which of the following cannula should be preferred for fluid resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to ATLS guidelines, a minimum of 2 large bore IV lines preferably of 18 gauge (green) marked as "1" should be used for fluid resuscitation of trauma patients with large volume loss.

For trauma patients who necessitate a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred.

The rate of flow is proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the cannula and inversely related to its length, as described in Poiseuille’s law. Hence, short, large-caliber peripheral intravenous lines are preferred for the rapid infusion of fluid, rather than longer, thinner catheters. Higher the gauge of the cannula, lower the caliber of the cannula.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses
14G Orange 270ml/min Trauma Patients, Rapid, Large Volume replacement
16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids
17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics
22G Blue 42 ml/min Small or Fragile veins, Cytotoxic Therapy
24G Yellow 20ml/min For pediatric Usage
26G Violet 13ml/min Newly added

questions.text: The sign shown below occurs due to the paralysis of
questions.solution:
The above image shows Trendelenberg test being done.

  • This test is positive in case of paralysis or weakness of gluteus medius muscle.
  • Gluteus medius is supplied by superior gluteal nerve and it performs 3 functions – hip abduction, medial rotation and pelvic rotation.

Trendelenberg test : 

In case of paralysis of gluteus medius muscle, pelvic rotation doesn’t occur and gravity pulls the pelvis of unsupported leg down and Trendelenberg test is said to be positive.

It is also positive in case of :

  • Fracture of the femoral neck
  • Hip dislocation

questions.text: The Marking ‘1’ in the below image of a sarcomere denotes:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a Sarcomere.

The marking 1 denotes H zone.

H zone or H band denotes the less refractile region in the centre of A band.

  • A band – Anisotropic / Dark band.
    • Formed by thick filaments - Myosin
  • I band – Isotropic / Light band
    • Formed by thin filaments – Actin, Troponin, Tropomyosin
  • M line – Seen in the centre of H band.
    • Due to central bulge of A band
  • Z line – Seen in the centre of each I band.
    • Narrow line with high refractile material appearing dark.

Structural muscle proteins:

  • Actinin – Binds Z lines to actin
  • Titin – Connects Z lines to M line
  • Desmin – Connects Z lines to cell membrane

questions.text: Condition seen in the photograph is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
This is an image of Casal's necklace which is seen in the case of Pellagra which occurs due to Niacin deficiency.

The triad of dermatitis, diarrhoea and dementia is characteristic of pellagra. It occurs due to the deficiency of vitamin B3 (niacin). 

Causes of Pellagra:

  • Dietary deficiency caused due to a corn-based diet - maize and jowar
  • Alcoholics
  • Hartnup disease -  Congenital defects of intestinal and kidney absorption of tryptophan
  • Tryptophan deficiency
  • Deficiency of micronutrients (e.g., iron, riboflavin, and pyridoxine)
  • Isoniazid can precipitate pellagra deficiency
  • The antitubercular drug isoniazid, a structural analogue of niacin, can precipitate pellagra.

Symptoms of pellagra -

  • Bright red glossitis followed by characteristic scaling and pigmentation of the skin that is exposed to the sun
  • Diarrhoea
  • Depression
  • Dementia
  • Seizures

Pellagra can be fatal if not treated promptly.

Diagnosis:

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

Treatment:

Oral supplementation with 100 - 200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid - 5 days.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text: Most appropriate about the given histopathological image is:

choices.text: IgG antibodies against Dsg-1 and Dsg -3

questions.solution:
The given histopathological image above depicts a ‘Tomb stone appearance’of intact keratinocytes.

It is characteristic of Pemphigus Vulgaris in which IgG antibodies are present against Desmoglein 3 and Desmoglein 1.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: Identify the crystal depicted in urine microscopy
questions.solution:
The above image of urine microscopy shows coffin lid like crystals which are characteristic of struvite crystals.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: The sonography demonstrates:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasonograph demonstrates overlapping skull bones, also known as Spalding sign. 

Option A: Spalding sign

  • The irregular overlapping of cranial bones on one another is due to liquefaction of brain and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the vault.
  • It usually appears 7 days after death

Option B: Roberts sign

  • Earliest sign of IUD - seen within 12 hours of death
  • The presence of gas shadow within the chambers of the heart and in large vessels of the fetus.

Option C: Blair-Hartley/Ball: sign 

  • Hyperextension/hyperflexion of spine with crowding of ribs
  • Usually seen 3-4 weeks after death
Sign Interval (After Death)
Robert sign (gas in great vessels) 12h
Spalding sign (overlapping of skull bones) 1 week
Blair-Hartley / Ball sign (hyperflexion / hyperextension of spine over ovecrowding of ribs) 3-4 weeks

questions.text: A 5 yr old girl is brought to you by her mother, stating that the girl drinks a lot of water. Physical examination shows slight protusion of her eyes. Further work-up reveals the presence of multiple lytic bone lesions involving the calvarium and base of her skull. What is the most likely diagnosis for this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture suggests that the girl has Hand Schuller Christian disease.

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH):

  • A spectrum of clinical diseases associated with the proliferation of Langerhans cells.
  • These cells contain distinctive granules, seen on electron microscopy – Rod shaped tennis racket or Birbeck granules.
  • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease (Multifocal LCH) –
    • Common in 2 - 6 years of life
    • The characteristic triad consists of:
      • Bony lytic skull lesions
      • Exopthalmos
      • Diabetes insipidus
  • Letterer-Siwe disease (Acute disseminated LCH):
    • Affects children before 3 yrs of age
    • Features
      • Seborrheic lesions,
      • Anaemia, thrombocytopenia
      • Recurrent infections
      • Clinical course is usually rapidly fatal
  • Unifocal Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophillic granuloma)is a localized form of histiocytosis, a benign lesion of proliferating Langerhans' cells. It is the least severe of the histiocytosis syndromes, and is characterized by lytic lesions of one or more bones.
  • Seen in older patients, mostly affecting the skeletal system.

questions.text: The following image shows the chest X-ray of a preterm neonate who was admitted to the NICU in view of severe respiratory distress.  What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture of respiratory distress in a premature neonate and the X-ray findings of diffuse ground-glass (reticulo-granular) opacities with a characteristic white-out appearance, hyaline membrane disease (HMD) is the most likely diagnosis.

HMD, also known as neonatal Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a relatively common condition resulting from insufficient production of surfactant that occurs in preterm neonates. Maternal diabetes, perinatal asphyxia, and multiple gestations are other known risk factors for the condition. Clinical features include tachypnea, chest retractions, expiratory grunting, and nasal flaring. The infant may or may not be cyanosed. 

X-ray features of HMD include:

  • Air bronchogram sign
  • Diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • Obliteration of cardiac and diaphragmatic contours giving rise to 'white-out' lung (indicates severe disease)

 

Chest radiograph (A) shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

questions.text: Following type of tympanogram is seen in
questions.solution:
The given diagram represents type C type of tympanogram with normal compliance and negative pressure. It is seen in case of retracted tympanic membrane.

Tympanogram:

Result of tympanometry is plotted in form of tympanogram with:

  • Compliance on Y axis (ease of mobility of TM)
  • Middle ear pressure on X axis (regulated by eustachian tube)

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Identify the sign in the given image
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Antral Sign / Holman Miller sign which is characteristic of Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma.

It refers to anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus.

Option A:

Tear drop sign

  • Seen in orbital floor fracture also known as blow out fracture.
  • It is due to herniation of orbital contents into maxillary antrum.

 

Option B:

Phlep's sign

  • Seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor.
  • It is erosion of normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

questions.text: The ECG given below is seen in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The blue arrows in the above ECG point to the J wave or the Osborn wave or the camel hump waves. This wave is seen in Hypothermia.

Option B: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

Option C: STEMI shows ST segment elevation not J wave elevation on ECG.

Option D: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.

questions.text: The image given below represents
questions.solution:
The given image shows Mc Roberts maneuver.

All of the above mentioned maneuvers are used for management of shoulder dystocia.

Mc Roberts maneuver:

  • In this maneuver, legs of the mother will be abducted and flexed against the abdomen.
  • It causes cephalad rotation of the pelvis.
  • Along with this gentle suprapubic pressure is applied by the assistant.

Option b:

Woods corkscrew maneuver -

Pressure is applied anteriorly to the posterior shoulder and it is abducted and rotated 1800 anteriorly so that the impacted anterior shoulder is disimpacted.

Option C:

Cleidotomy It refers to cutting of clavicle with the help of scissors to facilitate delivery of the fetus.

It is procedure of choice in case of a living anencephalic baby and in case of a dead fetus.

Option D:

Zavanelli maneuver -

In this maneuver head is rotated back to its prerestitution position and caeserian section is preformed once the head is back in the pelvis.

questions.solution:
Option a: Rashtriya swasthya bima yojana

Option c: Integrated child development services

Option d: Mission indradhanush

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a Barium meal. (The condition depicted is trichobezoar which shows a filling defect in a barium meal X-ray)

Barium is used as a contrast for GI imaging.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheo esophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used
  • Perforation peritonitis: Gastrograffin-Ionic water soluble agent is used

Procedures: For Single contrast films barium alone is used. Double contrast films requires air and barium which is better for small mucosal lesion.

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus)
  • Ba meal- 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum)
  • Ba meal follow through -50% BaSO4 (for small bowel)
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel)

Enteroclysis - gastrointestinal technique designed to provide improved evaluation of the small bowel from jejunum to ileocecal junction. It is done by intubating the jejunum and instillation of the contrast material through the tube.

The conventional fluoroscopic technique is not widely used since it is somewhat invasive, time and labour intensive, and not particularly pleasant for the patient. Modifications of the tradition technique may involve CT or MRI. It is indicated for examination of mucosal detail of the small intestine and improved evaluation of small bowel tumours or inflammatory disease.

questions.text: The following type of wound can be seen in all, except ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stellate/ cruciate type of wound, which is seen in a contact shot, not in a close shot.

Close-shot wound features include wounds with the victim within a range of 5 to 8 cm, characterized by circular shapes with inverted edges. Notable signs include blackening and tattooing around the wound area. Additionally, there may be burning of hair, along with abrasion and the presence of a grease collar.

Other options:

Option A: Bursting of the skull is associated with a contact shot wound.  

Option B: Firearm exit wounds can be of various shapes, such as round, cruciate, stellate, elliptical, or crescent-shaped. Exit wounds of the head are usually star-shaped.

Option C: Contact shot features are :

  • An imprint of muzzle around the wound – Recoil abrasion.
  • Back spatter - Sucking of tissue, Cloth fibers, inside the barrel.
  • Pinkish-red discoloration due to CO.
  • Shape - Stellate, Cruciate, Elliptical.
  • Margins - everted.
  • Bursting fractures – In head wounds.
  • Cavitation - abdominal wounds.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing focal foveal detachment.

There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment.

Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central serous choriopathy (CSC).

If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen.

Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are contraindicated.

questions.text: The below diagram shows the epiploic foramen. The structure marked in the figure corresponds to the superior boundary. What structure is it?
questions.solution:
The structure is caudate lobe.

Caudate lobe forms the superior boundary of epiploic foramen.

                          Epiploic foramen
Boundaries Structures
Anterior Lesser omentum and portal triad (hepatic artery, bile duct and portal vein)
Posterior (SIT)

Suprarenal gland

IVC

T12 vertebra
Superior Caudate process of liver
Inferior

First part of duodenum 

Horizontal part of hepatic artery

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below
questions.solution:
The egg in the given picture indicates hookworm egg.

Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus(new world hookworm) are identical.

The eggs of hookworm are :

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless,
  • Not bile stained,
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell.
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta
questions.solution:
This is an image of battledore placenta where cord is inserted at the margin or within 2 cm of the margin of placenta.

Option b: 

Circumvallate placenta

Fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery which is made of double fold of amnionand chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between.

Option c:

Velamentous placenta

Cord is attached to the membrane and blood vessels pass through the membrane and then reach the placenta to supply it.

Option d:

Succenturiate placenta

One or more small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with 2 weeks of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest radiogram was done as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has a lung abscess, as the chest X-ray shows an air-fluid level. Clindamycin is the drug of choice for treating lung abscesses.

Chest X-ray showing lung abscess(yellow) with air-fluid level (arrow):

Clindamycin is preferred over penicillin for primary lung abscesses (caused by aspirating oral flora in healthy individuals) due to its effectiveness against β-lactamase-producing anaerobes. Recommended treatments include IV clindamycin followed by oral clindamycin or a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination like amoxicillin-clavulanate. Therapy continues until imaging confirms resolution. Metronidazole alone is ineffective since it does not cover microaerophilic streptococci.

Secondary lung abscesses (caused by underlying conditions like malignancy, immunosuppression, or bronchial obstruction) are treated by targeting the identified pathogen and prolonging antibiotic courses based on the patient’s immune status. If no improvement is seen in 7 days, further evaluation is needed to rule out underlying causes.

Large abscesses (>6–8 cm) are less likely to resolve without additional interventions, such as drainage or surgery. Patients who fail antibiotic therapy, especially if they are poor surgical candidates, may require surgical resection or percutaneous drainage. Possible complications of drainage include pleural infection, pneumothorax, and hemothorax.

Note: Pneumatoceles are thin-walled cavities in the lung parenchyma that are seen in respiratory tract infections. They are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus in children and Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. Below is the chest X-ray showing a pneumatocele.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with a single episode of loss of consciousness. He was about to give a speech at his graduation ceremony when he suddenly turned pale and collapsed to the ground. Which of the following areas contain the nerve responsible for it?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a vasovagal syncope triggered by a stressful event. The vagus nerve is a content of the carotid triangle marked as 1.

In the given image:

  1. Carotid triangle
  2. Occipital triangle 
  3. Subclavian triangle
  4. Digastric triangle

Contents of the carotid triangle:

  • Arteries:
    • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
    • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Veins:
    • Internal jugular vein
    • Common facial vein
    • Lingual vein
  • Nerves:
    • Vagus nerve
    • Hypoglossal nerve
    • Spinal part of accessory
    • Sympathetic chain
    • Ansa cervicalis

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: The flap shown in the picture is which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the reconstruction of chest wall (pectoral region) using a Serratus Anterior flap.The flap has been rotated from lateral to medial to cover the defect on the pectoral region.

Serratus anterior

  • Origin: Lateral surfaces of upper 8-9 ribs and deep fascia overlying the related intercostal spaces
  • Insertion: Costal surface of medial border of scapula 
  • Innervation: Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Bood supply : Lateral thoracic artery (upper part), thoracodorsal artery (lower part)

Classification of muscle flaps

Based on blood supply Method of movement

Based on composition

 

 

Random pattern flap 

Unnamed vessel supplying flap

Local transfer 

-Rotation flap

-Transposition flap

-Advancement flap

Simple Flap

-Cutaneous flap

-Musculocutaneous 

-Fasciocutaneous 

Axial pattern flap

Named vessel supplying flap

Distant transfer 

-Pedicle flap

-Free flap

Composite flap

-Osseocutaneous flap

-Sensory flap

 

Note:

The image is not a Pectoral myocutaneous flap as the defect is on the pectoral region which has been covered using a Serratus Anterior flap.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument
questions.solution:
This is the image of Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA).

It aids in intubation in case of difficult airway.

Position:

  • Distal tip lies against the Upper esophageal sphincter.
  • Proximal tip juxtaposed with base of the tongue.
  • Side cuffs cover pyriform fossa.

Contraindications:

  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Pharyngeal obstruction
  • Restrictive airway disease
  • Hiatal hernia
  • Pregnancy

Option a:

Guedel airway -

It is an oral airway which is used to create and maintain air passage between tongue and posterior pharyngeal wall.

Option c:

Endotracheal tube -

Endotracheal intubation is usually performed emergency procedure to secure airway where endotracheal tube is placed in the trachea by passing it through mouth or nose.

Option d:

Nasogastric tube –

It is passed into the stomach via nose. It has many diagnostic and therapeutic uses like aspiration of stomach contents, evaluation of upper GI bleed, stomach wash in case of poisoning etc.

questions.text: The following reflex disappears at
questions.solution:
This image shows parachute reflex which is a protective reflex. It never disappears.

Timing of primitive reflexes:

Reflex Onset Fully developed Duration
Palmar grasp 28 week gestation 32 week gestation 2-3 month postnatal
Rooting 32 week gestation 36 week gestation Less prominent after 1 month postnatal, disappears by 4th month
Moro 28-32 week gestation 37 week gestation 5-6 month postnatal
Tonic neck 35 week gestation 1 month postnatal 6-7 month postnatal
Parachute 7-8 month postnatal 10-11 month postnatal Remains throughout life

questions.text: Substance inhibiting the complex I in electron transport chain is
questions.solution:
Complex I in electron transport chain is inhibited by Amobarbital.

Inhibitors of ETC:

  • Complex I – Amobarbital, piericidin A, rotenone
  • Complex II – Carboxin, malonate, TTFA (Trienoyl Tri Fluoro Acetone)
  • Complex III – Antimycin A, British Antilevisite (dimercaprol)
  • Complex IV (Cytochrome c Oxidase) – CO, Cyanide, H2S, Sodium Azide

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: The given mosquito is the vector for all of the following diseases except
questions.solution:
The given image shows Aedes aegypti mosquito and it does not transmit Kyasanur forest disease.

It is also known as tiger mosquito since it has white stripes against black body.

It acts as a vector for transmission of: Mnemonic: (DRY Chicken)

  • Dengue
  • Rift valley feve
  • Yellow fever
  • Chikungunya

 

Kyasanur forest disease is transmitted by the bite of ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera).

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about the given dose response curve

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D

questions.solution:
The more the curve on the left, more is its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • More the curve on the left side, more is its potency.
  • Hence in the given DRC drug B is most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.
  • Hence in the given DRC, drug B has least efficacy and drug A, C & D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: The following procedure was first performed by
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above picture is spinal anesthesia. The first case of spinal anesthesia in humans was performed by August Bier in 1898. He performed spinal anesthesia using the local anesthetic cocaine.

Spinal anesthesia involves the administration of a local anesthetic into the spinal subarachnoid space to provide motor and sensory blockade.

Other options:

  • John Lundy - coined the term balanced anesthesia. 
  • Edmund Boyle - discovered the anesthetic machine. 
  • Oliver Wendell - coined the term anesthesia.

questions.text: The given graph 2 represents
questions.solution:
The given graph indicates competitive inhibition since the Km is increased and Vmax has remained the same(Vmax/2 has remained the same).

  • Km is the substrate concentration at which velocity is half maximum.
  • Vmax is the maximum velocity of a reaction.
Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases

questions.text: Which organism shows the below depicted phenomenon when incubated with staphylococcus aureus on blood agar
questions.solution:
The given image shows the phenomenon of satellitism which is exhibited by Haemophilus influenzae when incubated on blood agar along with Staphylococcus.

  • Factor V produced by Staph aureus helps in growth of Haemophilus.
  • Haemophilus colonies will be larger and well developed alongside the streak of staphylococcus aureus since V factor diffuses into surrounding medium.
  • This is known as satellitism.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a 7-month history of erythema and swelling of the periorbital region and papules and plaques of the dorsolateral aspect of the forearms, DIP and knuckles with ragged cuticles. There was no muscle weakness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely clinical diagnosis from the given clinical history and the image which shows gottron’s papules is dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune disorder affecting, pre-dominantly women around 50-60 years of age with the involvement of skin and skeletal muscle.

Clinical features include a characteristic erythematous rash around eyelids with periorbital edema known as heliotrope rash. Symmetric, proximal greater than distal muscle weakness is present.

Gottron’s papules are inflammatory, red, flat‐topped, lichenoid lesions on the skin present over the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Mechanic’s hands denote non‐inflammatory hyperkeratosis occurring on the hands or feet. V sign presents as rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest and shawl sign with rashes on the back of the neck and shoulders. Hypertrophic ragged cuticles are typical.

Other signs of dermatomyositis include periungual telangiectasia, poikiloderma, calcinosis cutis and diffuse non‐scarring hair loss.

Anti‐Jo‐1 antibody is commonly associated with this condition. Serum creatinine kinase levels are elevated in majority of the patients.

Management includes systemic corticosteroids which are usually effective.  

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed to have an aneurysmal malformation of a vessel located in the marked structure. Identify the structure and the vessel present in it.
questions.solution:
The area marked "A" is the quadrigeminal cistern, and it contains the great cerebral vein of Galen.

Aneurysmal malformation of the great cerebral vein of Galen is a congenital anomaly occurring due to the persistence of the embryonic prosencephalic vein of Markowski. 

The image below is a CT cerebral angiogram of a vein of Galen malformation and an abnormal falcine sinus.

Related Pearl: Subarachnoid Cisterns

Subarachnoid cistern Interpeduncular / basal cistern Cisterna Magns ( Cerebellomedullary cistern )- largest cistern Quadrigeminal cistern/ Superior cistern/ vein of Galen cistern/ Peripineal cistern Cerebellopontine cistern Pontine cistern Sylvian/Lateral sulcus cistern
Location Base of brain in the interpeduncular fossa Angle between the inferior surface of cerebellum and medulla. Continuous with the IV ventricle through foramen of Magendie Between the splenium of corpus callosum and superior cerebellar surface behind the midbrain Lateral angle between the cerebellum and pons Ventral surface of the pons Over the lateral sulcus
Content Circle of Willis, origins of anterior inferior cerebellar and superior cerebellar arteries and abducens nerves Vertebral arteries, origin of PICA, cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII. Great cerebral vein of Galen V, VII and VIII cranial nerves, anterior inferior cerebellar arteries, superior petrosal veins Basilar artery Middle cerebral artery and veins
